title: The Crucifixion of Jesus
shortSummary: Matthew 27 details the events leading to the crucifixion of Jesus Christ, including His trial before Pilate, the betrayal by Judas, the mocking by soldiers, His death on the cross, and His burial. This chapter highlights the fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy and the sacrificial nature of Christ's death for the redemption of sinners.
timeline: c. AD 30 - The Passion Week, the trial, crucifixion, and burial of Jesus Christ

keyCharacters.name: Jesus Christ
keyCharacters.description: The Son of God and Messiah who is tried, crucified, and buried in this chapter, fulfilling prophecy and offering Himself as a sacrifice for sin.

keyCharacters.name: Pontius Pilate
keyCharacters.description: The Roman governor who presides over Jesus' trial, ultimately authorizing His crucifixion despite finding no fault in Him.

keyCharacters.name: Judas Iscariot
keyCharacters.description: The disciple who betrays Jesus for thirty pieces of silver and later repents, leading to his tragic death.

keyCharacters.name: Chief Priests and Elders
keyCharacters.description: Jewish religious leaders who conspire to have Jesus put to death and influence the crowd to demand His crucifixion.

keyCharacters.name: Joseph of Arimathaea
keyCharacters.description: A wealthy disciple who courageously requests Jesus' body from Pilate and provides a tomb for His burial.

definitions.definition: A field purchased with the thirty pieces of silver returned by Judas, used as a burial place for strangers, symbolizing the price of betrayal.
To be whipped or flogged as a form of punishment; Jesus was scourged before His crucifixion as part of His suffering.
The place of the skull; the site outside Jerusalem where Jesus was crucified.
The thick curtain separating the Holy of Holies from the rest of the temple; its tearing at Jesus' death signifies direct access to God through Christ.
Aramaic for 'My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?' Jesus' cry expressing His suffering and fulfillment of Psalm 22.

outline.heading: Jesus Betrayed and Delivered to Pilate
outline.description: The chief priests and elders conspire to put Jesus to death; Judas repents and returns the silver, then dies. The priests use the silver to buy the potter's field, fulfilling prophecy.

outline.heading: Jesus Before Pilate and the Crowd's Choice
outline.description: Jesus stands silent before Pilate despite accusations. Pilate offers to release Jesus or Barabbas; the crowd chooses Barabbas and demands Jesus' crucifixion, leading Pilate to symbolically wash his hands of the matter.

outline.heading: Mocking, Crucifixion, and Death of Jesus
outline.description: Jesus is mocked by soldiers, forced to carry His cross, and crucified at Golgotha. Darkness covers the land, Jesus cries out in anguish, and then dies, accompanied by supernatural signs including the temple veil tearing and an earthquake.

outline.heading: Resurrection Foretold and Burial of Jesus
outline.description: The graves open and saints are raised after Jesus' resurrection. Joseph of Arimathaea buries Jesus in a new tomb, and faithful women watch over the burial site.

outline.heading: The Guard at the Tomb
outline.description: The chief priests and Pharisees request Pilate to secure Jesus' tomb to prevent His disciples from stealing the body and claiming resurrection, leading to the sealing of the tomb and posting of guards.

application: Trust in Jesus' sacrifice as the fulfillment of God's plan for salvation, recognizing His innocence despite suffering.
Respond to betrayal and sin with repentance, but also seek God's grace to avoid despair like Judas.
Stand firm in faith and courage like Joseph of Arimathaea, who honored Jesus even in death.
Remember that Jesus' death grants believers direct access to God, encouraging boldness in prayer and worship.

keyVerses.text: When Pilate saw that he could prevail nothing, but that rather a tumult was made, he took water, and washed his hands before the multitude, saying, I am innocent of the blood of this just person: see ye to it.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows Pilate's attempt to avoid responsibility for Jesus' death, highlighting human injustice contrasted with Jesus' innocence.

keyVerses.text: And about the ninth hour Jesus cried with a loud voice, saying, Eli, Eli, lama sabachthani? that is to say, My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?
keyVerses.significance: Jesus' cry reveals the depth of His suffering and fulfills prophecy, emphasizing His substitutionary atonement.

keyVerses.text: And, behold, the veil of the temple was rent in twain from the top to the bottom; and the earth did quake, and the rocks rent;
keyVerses.significance: The tearing of the temple veil symbolizes the new access to God made possible through Christ's death.

keyVerses.text: Now when the centurion, and they that were with him, watching Jesus, saw the earthquake, and those things that were done, they feared greatly, saying, Truly this was the Son of God.
keyVerses.significance: This confession from a Roman centurion affirms Jesus' divine identity even at the moment of His death.
